audio_caption: The audio begins with upbeat, pop-style music, creating a cheerful mood. A female speaker starts, her voice friendly and enthusiastic, announcing she'll show how she takes notes on her iPad Pro. She moves on to the hardware, mentioning her 2017 10.5-inch iPad Pro from Amazon renewed, priced at $350, and shares her experience checking it for damage. She highlights the Amazon's 90-day return policy. She then mentions a $12 basic iPad case with a folding magnetic screen, followed by the Apple Pencil. The music fades out.

The clip begins with a single female speaker with a positive and enthusiastic tone discussing an Apple Pencil. She highlights its durability, writing quality, comfort, and how a paper-like screen protector enhances the experience. The speaker notes that she orders all her products off Amazon and will leave the links below. The clip ends with a question: "So why digital note-taking?".

The audio begins with a young female speaker discussing her note-taking methods at the beginning of university. She describes creating "really detailed, color-coded notes" and recording lectures to listen to at home. Her tone is calm and reflective. She continues discussing how she shifted away from taking notes by hand, noting that "writing by hand on paper also just takes a lot of time." She is speaking in a matter-of-fact tone. She praises the combination of typing speed with the benefits of hand-written notes for learning. She continues to say, "for apps, I use the app good notes to take all of my notes."

The audio features a single female speaker promoting an app. She mentions its price on the app store, then lists convenience, simplicity of the interface, and ease of organization as reasons to use it. She describes her organizational system of folders and subfolders for different classes, and states she keeps all class-related information on the app, avoiding switching between printouts and other programs.

A single female speaker begins the clip in a conversational tone, describing their preferences for taking notes in GoodNotes: they use a "standard notebook" with a brown cover and black binding, A5-sized gridded paper, and how the grid helps them write straight. The speaker adds that "A5 size is small enough" so the page doesn't seem overloaded. They mention not using the app's zoom feature because they don't always reach the end of the line, so the smaller page size is an alternative.

The audio clip features a single female speaker discussing her usage of the GoodNotes app for note-taking. She starts by listing the pens available in the app, mentioning her preference for the ball pen and explaining why she avoids the others. Her tone is casual and conversational as she elaborates on pen sizes and color choices for her notes, and the highlighter options she uses for important information. The only background audio is a quiet hum, that creates a simple ambient setting.

A female speaker discusses how she takes notes, saying it "differs from class to class," depending on if the professor provides PowerPoints. She outlines how she writes directly on the PowerPoint itself, writes in a lecture-style notebook, or does not take notes at all. She explains that she doesn't feel the need to write down notes if she already knows the material, or the professor just reads from a PowerPoint. The speaker adds that she puts more effort into revising, but still emphasizes the importance of writing notes "that you understand." As she finishes speaking, there is a transition to upbeat, cheerful music.

The audio clip begins with a woman speaking in a clear, instructional tone. She explains her note-taking system, starting with "it's really simple and it works for me." She goes on to describe writing the date in the upper right corner, mentioning it helps with revision and referencing when something was taught. She then says she usually writes the topic title at the top of the page and highlights or circles it.

A female speaker describes her note-taking system, explaining how she uses bullet points for general information, dashes for more specific information, and arrows for even more specific information, then restarts the cycle. She emphasizes that her simple system helps her remember signifiers and take clean notes without being overwhelmed.

The audio clip features one female speaker describing their note-taking process. They mention highlighting important statements or essential information from PowerPoint presentations and pre-made notes. A second color is used to draw diagrams or add extra information for clarification. The speaker adds an asterisk to note specifically what their professor says will be on an exam. The speaker emphasizes they write this information in the form of a practice question so they can review later.

The clip begins with a female speaker assessing her notes from a biology textbook, describing them as "basically useless" due to too much information. She continues by reflecting on how mnemonics, flashcards, or practice tests could have been better study methods than rote note-taking. She mentions transitioning to Anki flashcards for reinforcement and self-testing, finding it more practical and time-efficient. The speaker's tone throughout is conversational and reflective.

The clip features a single female speaker with a friendly and conversational tone. She encourages viewers, emphasizing the importance of functionality in note-taking over mere aesthetics, and promises a video next week before signing off. The speech is set against the backdrop of upbeat, calming electronic music, creating a relaxed atmosphere.
